title: Macquarie Group to sell Martin Place metro precinct tower
text:
The successful buyer will comply with the already approved development scheme and timeline to complete the tower by 2024 when the metro line opens, as set out in the agreement between Macquarie and the NSW government.

39 Martin Place. Supplied

As a leasing campaign has not kicked off, the new owner will also be able to source its own tenants for the world-class tower as well as its companion lower ground retail precinct, designed by architects Tzannes and Grimshaw respectively.

Considered a "once in a generation" opportunity, 39 Martin Place - located on the site of the former Tiffany & Co. flagship store - will yield 30,000sq m of premium office space, with floorplates as large as 1100sq m.

It will also bear a 1300sq m podium, end-of-trip facilities and naming rights for its owner.

The south tower at Martin Place metro station precinct. Supplied

The tower will have 1000sq m of retail space on the ground and mezzanine levels and another 1000sq m of underground space integrated with the new metro station.

It is understood Macquarie has put the tower on the market following several prior offers and also because it won't be occupying the tower unlike the north tower on Castlereagh, Hunter and Elizabeth Streets.

Advertisement

That tower will also integrate with the metro as well as Macquarie's current headquarters at the heritage-listed 50 Martin Place creating a big office "campus" for the financial firm.

The 39-storey north tower is bigger with 75,498sq m of space including 1017sq m for retail use.

Lendlease has been appointed to build both towers, the new metro station and its new underground pedestrian connections.

When completed, the network of towers and underground passages will emulate other well-known global transport precincts such as the New York’s World Trade Centre station and Hong Kong’s International Finance Centre.
description: Macquarie Group will steer its own expressions of interest campaign for the prime tower at 39 Martin Place.
